member.name: AssertEnumMember{TEnum}(TEnum,string)
member.summary: Ensures the specified enumeration argument is a valid member of the enumeration. If it is not, an is thrown.

remarks.para: This method can be used to validate all publicly-supplied enumeration values. Without such an assertion, it is possible to cast any int value to the enumeration type and pass it in.

This method works for both flags and non-flags enumerations. In the case of a flags enumeration, any combination of values in the enumeration is accepted. In the case of a non-flags enumeration, must be equal to one of the values in the enumeration.

This method is generic and quite slow as a result. You should prefer using the overload where possible. That overload is both faster and safer. Faster because it does not incur reflection costs, and safer because you are able to specify the exact values accepted by your method.

member.exception: If is not a valid member of the enumeration.

remarks.para: This method can be used to ensure that an enumeration argument is valid for the context of the method. It works for both flags and non-flags enumerations. For flags enumerations, must be any combination of values specified by . For non-flags enumerations, must be one of the values specified by .

This method is much faster than the overload. This is because it does not use reflection to determine the values defined by the enumeration. For this reason you should prefer this method when validating enumeration arguments.

Another reason why this method is prefered is because it allows you to explicitly specify the values that your code handles. If you use the overload and a new value is later added to the enumeration, the assertion will not fail but your code probably will.
